concept.title: toolkit for java
concept.shortdesc: What does the Toolkit do and how does it go about solving documentation problems.

section.p: To overcome the problems of developer mindsets, bad documentation practises, lack of any link between user and system doc; The toolkit was created, each part of the suite contributes to the practise of good technical doc.

section.title: System Doc
section.p: System doc is more the "how" systems work and are linked together. By using Taglets, this information can be captured within the code, using diagrams to explain how different parts of the systems work. System doc is vital for developer onboarding. By having images and text within the code, but without making the code too bloated, there is a link now between the code and the documentation.

section.title: User Doc
section.p: Is what gets externally exposed to the end user, having developers contribute to the user manual is key, but it has to be simple to produce. Javadoc is a good way of documenting Class and Method contracts and functionality, again using Taglets is a good way of enhancing that information. Makeing sure that the comments match the code, and adhere to standards, is a key component of the toolkit.

section.title: Why use DITA?
section.p:
DITA allows for some very important concepts that the development community will easily get to grips with.
A topic oriented approach for Doc.
Markdown XML content.
Content reuse.
Supports inheritance and extensibility.
Ant based processing.
Multi channel publishing.
Content and style are broken apart.
Content can be created on any platform and in any development environment.
The DITA toolkit enables multi format publishing, and although can be difficult at times, aims to simplify this process allowing the developer to focus on content.
